title: labour party just ended nightmare
story: NewsopinionThe Labour Party just ended a nightmare for Britains forgotten heroesJustice delayed is justice denied. But it is better than no justice at allShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  SEP Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe call, when it came, dropped like a bomb out of a clear blue sky. Emily Thornberry is going to announce a manesto pledge on Monday to give every living nuclear test veteran £,.    I heard it but could not comprehend it. Right, I said. Seventeen years of covering the same story began to unfold in my head, like the fireballs the veterans have told me about, and a few seconds later the shockwave hit. My knees went from under me as the enormity of what a £m promise meant arrived at the back of my skull. Barry. Archie. Shirley. Ken. Mick and Rose, Lucy and John, Wendy, Jean, Dave, Shelley, John... Some are alive, and many are dead. But all have, finally, been heard.   Barry Smith was sent to Christmas Island in . It was his job to cut the hair of men decontaminating it after dozens of nuclear tests.When he developed a rare form of pancreatic cancer he applied for a war pension he could leave to his we Anna. With weeks to live, he struggled to a war pension appeal, which would hear evidence his cancer had been seen in the survivors of Hiroshima. The MoD lawyer stood, said they had not read it, and asked for an adjournment. Barry responded: Are you aware that Iaposm dying  It had taken all his strength to get there. He had no time left. The hearing was adjourned, and Barry died  days later. Anna was denied a widowaposs pension.    RAF pilot Eric Denson used to patrol the Iron Curtain in a Canberra bomber, testing the radar defences separating East and West. The dad of two was sent to Christmas Island in , and ed weeks later with a large red burn across his chest. His urbane personality had changed to being abrupt, dark, and destructive. He and we Shirley had two more children, but he suffered crippling headaches. He killed himself on the third attempt, in . Shirley raised their four girls alone. She saw grandchildren born, some with missing and extra teeth, others with spinal deformities. Years later she found documents from the MoD archives showing Eric had flown into a mushroom cloud, and in  minutes had  yearsapos worth of background radiation delivered directly to his brain. Chillingly, the documents called it the initial experiment.   Archie Ross died in , aged , of non-Hodgkinaposs lymphoma. For  years he had repeated hospital visits to cut away a layer of skin that had begun growing between his eyelid and eyeball. He had a grandchild with Downaposs, and his daughter Julie was born with a twisted ribcage and outsized arm. Ken McGinley was unable to have children. He founded the BNTVA and in  took their case to Strasbourg, and is now a full-time carer for his we. Shelly Grigg is living with Dercumaposs disease, a condition in which fatty tissue tumours grow in her abdomen and have to be surgically removed. Wendy Brothers still cries talking about the death of husband John, who had  brain tumours, and the babies they lost. Jean Sinfield took her late husband Bertaposs case all the way to the Supreme Court. Dave Whyte has had so many Freedom of Information battles with the MoD that at one point they refused to speak to him.   These are the people who for  years have been gaslighted by their own governments. They were told they were imagining the things that were a central feature of their lives. They have, unsurprisingly, elevated rates of anxiety, depression and mental illness. They said the same thing: Theyaposre waiting for us to die. Of the , men who took part in the hundreds of nuclear tests Britain held between  and  in America, Australia and the South Pacic, itaposs thought thereaposs only , alive. Justice delayed is justice denied, and that was never truer than for the , men who died on the way here. But some justice is better than none at all.   Some will say words are cheap, that politicians have said things before, and thereaposs no chance of a Labour government. But Emily Thornberryaposs promise is the first time anyone turned to those people, and said: We can hear you. When they heard the news, each veteran and widow said the same thing. Youaposre kidding me. Then: Oh my God. And finally: The money doesnapost matter. Theyaposve heard us. Every party has promised the veterans something in Opposition, only to forget it in power. But this time the Labour Party has made a clear manesto promise of doing more for its test veterans than any other nuclear power on Earth. This pledge is set in concrete now, and to break it will break them.  It might be decades before we see a Labour majority government. But when the Mirror campaigned to change the rules on organ donation, Labour made it a manesto pledge. The Tories nicked the idea, and the glory, and passed it into law. In a time of turmoil, with hung parliaments and coalitions, a pledge costing as little as £m can and will be used to build cross-party support. And at election time, Whitehall civil servants must prepare to enact all party manestos on day  of a new government. So the men in suits at the MoD, those bureaucrats so long blamed for blocking the veteransapos path, must finally do the sums that add up to official recognition. The institutional change in thinking that will require is itself a victory.    Widows do not qualy for this promise. Nor do dead men, or their children and grandchildren. But it is still a win for them. This is not the end. The test veterans never stopped fighting, and nor will we. Money for survivors must be matched with war pensions for widows, research and genetic counselling for descendants, and a medal from the Queen in honour of their courage. Those things are all more likely because of this promise. Today, the Labour Party has done a good thing. Emily Thornberry has put the test veterans centre stage, and dared the other parties to see what our country has done to them. To a government, £m is nothing. To an old man who watched the atom split, £, is not the point. Widows cannot get their men or their babies back. But they can be acknowledged and their minds put at ease. And, perhaps, this is the start of better weather for the test veterans. The clouds have finally begun to clear. Read the full story of Britainaposs nuclear test legacy at damned.mirror

Mike Hennessy, of Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, is a retired freelance advertising copywriter who says he and a colleague took just a couple of days to come up with the catchy phrase. He has always urged people he meets to book their holidays with Thomas Cook because the firm was so reliable, he said, so today#xs news of the collapse was #xironic#x and #xsad.#x Thomas Cook ceased trading in the early hours of the morning #xCAt the time we wrote the phrase, there were holiday companies going bust everywhere, they were sort of closing down and Thomas Cook were the only one out of any of the travel agents who actually offering  hours back money guarantee,#xD he recalled. #xCIn other words,your company went bust on you, you#xd be able to book a holiday there and then and still be going the following day and that#xs how it all really happened.#xD:Workers poignant messageA cabin crew worker has posted a poignant message following the collapse of her employer.Kia Dawn Hayward is one of , UK staff members whose jobs were wiped out when the company ceased trading.In a Twitter post she wrote: #xCLove my job so much, don#xt want it to end.#xCThank you for making my dream job come true #ThomasCook , you will always be my first ever airline and the last in my Sunny Heart#xD:. Glasgow Airport passengers affectedAn estimated , passengers travelling to and from Glasgow Airport have been hit by Thomas Cook#xs collapse.Airport chiefs say seven inbound and seven outbound flights were cancelled.The last of the firm#xs flights to arrive in the city landed at .am from Orlando in Florida, with seven inbound and seven outbound services grounded on Monday.:Thousands of Egypt reservations cancelled Thomas Cook operator Blue Sky Group has said that , reservations in Egypt booked up to April  had been cancelled. The cancellations came as Thomas Cook, the world#xs oldest travel firm, collapsed, forcing governments and insurance companies to coordinate a huge operation tohome some , travellers, including , Brits. Blue Sky currently has , Thomas Cook tourists in Egypt#xs Hugharda resort on the Red Sea, its chairman Hossam El-Shaer said in a statement sent to Reuters. The company was expecting , tourists to visit Egypt via Thomas Cook in , the statement added. Thousands of staff and holidaymakers have been affected by the companys collapse :Tearful staff at Thomas Cook HQSobbing Thomas Cook employees were today seen leaving the company#xs HQ today in tears after the travel firm went bust.More than , workers across the world have lost their jobs, including , in the UK, after it was confirmed the company had gone into administration.Earlier today solemn-faced workers emerged from the former travel giant#xs headquarters carrying plastic boxes filled with their belongings after news broke that they had lost their jobs.Staff outside the Thomas Cook headquarters in Peterborough :Company to be sold as a whole or in partsThomas Cook will be sold as a whole or in parts after its collapse, the company#xs second-largest shareholder said today - adding he would see what is offered before deciding whether to buy more assets. Neset Kockar, who holds an % stake in the UK-based travel firm, said Thomas Cook owes #xCa few hundred million pounds#xD to Turkish businesses that may not be paid after it is sold. Kockar is also the chairman of Turkey-based Anex Tour, which caters mainly to tourists from countries such as Russia and Ukraine.Thomas Cook will be sold in part or in full, it is claimed :Thomas Cook owes Tunisian hotels £mThomas Cook owes Tunisian hotels #xA million for stays in July and August, the country#xs tourism minister Rene Trabelsi told Reuters.He added that , British Thomas Cook customers are still in the country. Tourism is a vital sector for Tunisia#xs economy and a key source of foreign currency, and the government had expected another , Thomas Cook customers to visit this year, he added. #xCI will have a meeting on Tuesday with the British Embassy in Tunisia and the hotel owners to see how debt could be redeemed,#xD Trabelsi said. The companys collapse will have a big impact in Tunisia, the countrys tourism minister said :Final flight was in the air when firm collapsedPassengers onboard the last ever Thomas Cook flight have voiced their sympathy with staff - who found out that the company had collapsed while in the air.The landing at Manchester Airport brought an end to the company#xs  year history.Flight TCX left Orlando, Florida at .pm local time, shortly before the firm announced it was to cease trading with immediate effect.During the emotional flight, crew shared happy memories and jokes but also shed tears, with staff not knowing whether they would have jobs when they landed. But as they touched down in Manchester around .am, their worst fears were confirmed. The final Thomas Cook flight touched down at Manchester Airport this morning Elizabeth Evans, who was on the flight with husband Chris, both from Bury, Greater Manchester, said: #xCIt#xs a sad day, they#xve just landed and found out they#xve got no jobs. #xCThe pilot... he just kept thanking the staff and the lead hostess thanked the pilot.#xCIt#xs a sad day for them. It was sad to see them crying, staff, as we were getting off. One of the staff has done  years, now it#xs come to this. The plane was in the air when Thomas Cook ceased trading #xCIt#xs rubbish that it#xs gone bust.#xD Karen Connolly, who was with her partner Alan Cowling and son Jamie Cowling, all from Wolverhampton, said staff were #xCreally professional considering they probably won#xt get paid#xD.:Government defends decision not to bail out Thomas CookDowning Street has defended the decision not to use Government money to bail out Thomas Cook. Boris Johnson has been heavily criticised for failing to step in and save the company, which employed , people in the UK.A Number  spokeswoman said: #xCA bailout would not have been a good use of taxpayers#x money. We would have had to repatriate people later down the line and have lost more money in the process. The government has defended its decision not to bail out Thomas Cook #xCIt is obviously a very competitive market and it isn#xt the Government#xs role to prop up companies when this sort of issue arises. #xCOur decision was that injecting cash into the situation was not going to make it any better.#xD The spokeswoman said there would be #xCserious concerns#xD about some of the bonuses paid to the company#xs directors and that the directors#x conduct would form part of the Insolvency Service investigation. #xCPeople will rightly look at the size of the bonuses being paid to some of the directors and will have serious concerns about that,#xD she said.:KEY EVENTFirst Operation Matterhorn flight takes offThe operation to bring , stranded Brits back to the UK after the Thomas Cook collapse has begun.The first flight carrying the collapsed firm#xs customers has taken off from JFK Airport in New York.Pilots and staff from Atlas Air are operating the flight.Passenger Kirsty Devlin posted on Twitter: #xCWe#xre due to take off on chartered aircraft from NY to MCR. First ones to be repatriated.#xDThis morning transport secretary Grant Shapps said the cost of bringing holidaymakers home would be around #xA million.The first repatriation flight has taken off from New York The Government is working with the Civil Aviation Authority to bring Thomas Cook customers still abroad back home to the UK.Those currently overseas should check thomascook.caa for advice and only go to the airport once they have their alternative flight confirmed.The effort, named Operation Matterhorn, will be the largest repatriation effort in peacetime history, even bigger than when Monarch Airlines collapsed in .:TUI says come of its customers are affectedTravel company TUI has said some of its customers are affected by the collapse of Thomas Cook.Although it reassured passengers that the majority of flights and holidays will continue as normal, it said a number of package holidays that included flights with Thomas Cook have been cancelled due to an affiliation it had with the firm.#xC We really feel for everyone affected by the collapse of Thomas Cook,#xD a TUI spokesman told Mirror Money.#xCWe offer a small selection of TUI holidays featuring Thomas Cook flights, as well as a small number of Thomas Cook holidays through our stores.#xCWe are now working alongside the Civil Aviation Authorityto assist affected customers and help them to find alternative holidays or organise cancellations and full refunds.#xDThe Thomas Cook collapse has had a knock-on effect across the travel industry :Thomas Cook failed to move with times says expertThomas Cook went bust because it failed to compete with budget travel agencies and airlines, an industry expert said.Alana Gomez, spokesperson for flight-comparison site www.jetcost, said customers have turned their backs on package holidays in order to save money.She said: #xCWe have awoken with a heavy heart at this morning#xs news, and the British travel industry has lost one of its biggest players and largest influences. Not only have people had holidays and cruises cancelled, cut short or ruined by this news, but more than , people have lost their jobs around the world, including , here in the UK. It is a very sad situation, and seems incredibly counterintuitive that the company needed another #xA million to survive, whilst the repatriation effort is estimated to cost the UK around #xA million, just half of what the firm needed to survive.Thomas Cook failed to move with the times, an industry expert said #xCThe company unfortunately fell victim to being unable to adapt to the modern age, with its costs not competing with the more budget travel agencies and budget airlines. Furthermore, many more people are now becoming more adept at searching for the best deals, and booking inidual legs of their journey themselves, as opposed to booking package holidays, in order to save the most money. That being said, Thomas Cook is an institution and today#xs news has shook the travel industry #x hopefully it will encourage other travel agencies to adapt, and this will be the last news of this type for a long while.The company ceased trading in the early hours of the morning #xCThose that have booked package holidays are financially protected by ATOL, whilst those with holidays booked in the future will receive a full refund, although they will have to re-book their holiday with another agency, or call the trip off. If you are currently abroad and are due to fly home before the th October, then you will be flown home by a government-chartered plane, details of which are on a specially set-up website. If you are due to fly home after this date then you will need to find your own method of transportation, and only those with ATOL protection will be reimbursed.#xD:Turkey could lose , tourists a yearThe head of Turkey#xs Hoteliers Federation said Turkey could see ,-, fewer tourists annually.In an interview, Osman Ayik told Reuters there are currently , tourists in Turkey that came from the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe via Thomas Cook.The Federation#xs chairman added the company owes between #xA, and #xA, to some small hotels, which could suffer as a result of the collapse.:Dad spent £, vouchers hours before collapseA shrewd dad-of-five walked into a Thomas Cook shop just hours before the firm went bust and used #xA, vouchers on a holiday to New York - despite knowing it would never happen.Chris King and his we Steph had been saving the vouchers for a dream family holiday to Disneyland for when his three children, two-year-old twins Eloise and Theo and Xanthe, , were old enough.But after hearing that Thomas Cook were on the verge of going bust, he rushed down to his local store in Reading, Berkshire, and splashed out on last minute holiday just two hours before they closed in the hope he would be covered by ATOL protection.For the full story click hereChris and Steph at Heathrow Airport waiting to fly to Iceland in  :All quiet at Thomas Cook desksThomas Cook customers appear to be heeding calls not to go to airports this morning.Images from Birmingham Airport shows the company#xs desk completely deserted.Megan Archer, who posted the pictures, wrote: #xCAll quiet in the Thomas Cook section of @bhx_official - a message has been displayed on all screens informing passengers that the company has ceased trading. Staff are on hand today to assist anyone who needs it.#xD:Axed worker vows to carry on helpingAn axed Thomas Cook worker has pledged to stand outside the closed travel agents where she used to work in order to help affected travellers.Kindhearted Lucy Beatrice said she was determined to help anyone affected by the travel company closure - despite losing her job herself.The -year-old has said she would be at her branch from am as she admitted she was #xCdevastated beyond words#xD in a heartbreaking tweet.She said: #xCOfficially unemployed. Devastated beyond words. Even after us ceasing trading, I will be at my branch at am to help my customers with any questions.#xDFor the full story, click hereKindhearted Lucy has vowed to help affected travellers despite losing her job hours earlier :Devastated workers at Thomas Cook HQThomas Cook staff were seen hugging each other in tears at its headquarters in Cambridgeshire this morning after the holiday company collapsed.Hundreds of employees have been seen heading into the offices at Lynch Wood in Peterborough for a am meeting about the compulsory liquidation, which happened this morning after a weekend of talks to save the company.Many looked tearful as they arrived at the headquarters, which employs around , people.Thomas Cook was founded in  and was one of the world#xs oldest travel companies. It employed around , people in the UK and had around  high street stores.The firms UK headquarters are in Peterborough :Brexit not to blame for collapseThe Tory government today insisted Thomas Cook#xs collapse is absolutely nothing to do with Brexit after the holiday firm plunged into liquidation.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said there was no #xCBrexit connection#xD despite businesses dangling in uncertainty and the value of the pound - which has plummeted since the  EU referendum - hitting UK holidaymakers.The Cabinet minister instead blamed the crisis on Thomas Cook#xs #xClong term problems as a business#xD as its model is left out of date by the internet.Mr Hancock#xs comments do match recent reports on Thomas Cook, which have stressed the firm had been hit by high debt levels, online rivals and geopolitical uncertainty.However, he did not mention that Thomas Cook itself also warned uncertainty around Brexit was hitting bookings industry-wide four months ago.For the full story click hereMatt Hancock said Brexit is not to blame for Thomas Cooks collapse :, tourists stranded in GreeceAbout , tourists are stranded in Greece, mainly on islands, after Thomas Cook collapsed, a Greek tourism ministry official told Reuters on Monday. The tourists, mainly British, were vacationing on the islands of Zakynthos, Kos, Corfu, Skiathos and Crete, the official said. #xCThe top priority now is to get them back home,#xD the official said, declining to be named. Thomas Cook, one of Britain#xs oldest companies, ran hotels, resorts and airlines for  million people a year in  countries. The head of Greece#xs hotel federation said Thomas Cook#xs financial collapse would be a signicant blow for hoteliers, since many vacation packages were not prepaid. Thomas Cooks collapse has heaped misery on holidaymakers and staff #xCThe situation is quite dficult. It does not affect just British tourists but other nationalities as well,#xD Grigoris Tassios told state TV ERT. He said many hotels were expected to make losses on payments affecting vacation packages for the last two months, meaning #xCmany millions of euros#xD. #xCUp to October  there are high occupancies, so we will suffer losses from this segment, too,#xD Tassios said. He said hotel companies would turn to the courts to try and recover money owed by Thomas Cook.:Unite to launch legal action after collapseUnion bosses have vowed to take legal action on behalf of Thomas Cook workers who lost their jobs in the firm#xs collapse.The company, which has been operating for more than  years, ceased trading in the early hours of the morning.It employed , people in the UK, including , at the headquarters in Peterborough.Unite assistant general secretary Diana Holland said: #xCThe needless collapse of Thomas Cook is devastating for the workforce and customers. Thomas Cook Airlines was a profitable and viable operation with a loyal workforce..#xCInstead of stepping in and giving Thomas Cook the breathing space it needed to restructure its finances, the government#xs #xdo nothing#x attitude has left workers and customers high and dry while landing taxpayers with a bill of hundreds of millions of pounds.#xCUnite will be meeting the administrator and giving our members maximum support while working to match Thomas Cook Airline workers with other airlines that have vacancies. Unite will also be launching legal action on behalf of our members over a failure to consult on the redundancies that have resulted from the firm#xs collapse.#xD:Labour blast government for not saving Thomas CookShadow chancellor John McDonnell blamed the Tory Government#xs #xCideological bias#xD against state intervention for the decision not to intervene. Prime Minister Boris Johnson refused to bail the company out, describing it as a #xCmoral hazard#xDother companies run into financial trouble.He told the BBC: #xCThe Government#xs intervention could have enabled us to just stabilise the situation, give a breathing space so that there could be proper consultation with the workforce in particular about how to go forward. #xCTo just stand to one side and watch this number of jobs go and so many holidaymakers have their holiday ruined, I just don#xt think that#xs wise government.#xD Union bosses also condemned the Government#xs refusal to act, claiming that the cost of the exercise to bring stranded holidaymakers#x home would dwarf the amount of taxpayer support requested by the firm.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell hit out at the governments decision not to intervene :KEY EVENTLast ever Thomas Cook flight lands in ManchesterThe final Thomas Cook flight has touched down at Manchester Airport.Its arrival brings to an end the firm#xs long history, which began back in .For the full story click here.The last Thomas Cook flight has touched down in Manchester:What happens now for , UK workers The company employed , people worldwide including , in the UK alone and , at its head office in Peterborough.Union bosses have vowed to fight for jobs as furious critics say workers were #xCstabbed in the back#xD.Thomas Cook had around  shops in high streets across the UK, which have closed after the firm#xs collapse.For the full story click here.:Martin Lewis warns of refund headacheMoney saving expert Martin Lewis warns that Thomas Cook#xs collapse could leave thousands of customers out of pocket.The founder of MoneySavingExpert said: #xCThis is a sad day for staff and customers of Thomas Cook. In general those abroad now will be brought home once their holidays have finished. Most who haven#xt travelled will have a route to get their cash back, but this unprecedentedly large repatriation and refund operation will not be without problems. It#xs going to be a stressful time for many people #x MoneySavingExpert will be regularly updating our detailed help guide as we continue to learn more from officials and travellers.#xCThe Government has said all British travellers who were due to fly back within the next two weeks will be brought home free of charge. Those who#xve already paid for their hotels abroad as part of a Thomas Cook package shouldn#xt pay again. Yet that won#xt stop a few uncertain and scared hoteliers overseas wanting money directly from British travellers to be doubly sure. This could leave UK tourists in sticky situations. If so, the Civil Aviation Authority has a helpline which should sort it for you.#xCFor those who#xd booked future trips, ATOL and ABTA schemes should mean full refunds, but some, especially those who booked flights only, may be unprotected. Travel insurance won#xt help for most, as travel company failure cover is rarely included as standard #x though check your policy or give them a call.Passengers are seen at Thomas Cook check-in points at Mallorca Airport this morning #xCIf you did book without travel industry or insurance protection, the next route is your card provider. Those who paid more than #xA on a credit card get Section  legal protection #x which means the card firm is jointly liable with the retailer, so you can get your money back from it. However this may not workyou booked via an agency, or via certain PayPal transactions, as that break in the direct transactional relationship can stop it working #x we wait to see how widespread that problem will be.#xCIf that happens, or you paid by debit card, instead ask your bank to do a #xchargeback#x. This isn#xt a legal protection #x it is a Visa, Mastercard and Amex rule where your bank gets your money back from Thomas Cook#xs bank as you didn#xt receive what you paid for. It should work for most people. Those who paid by other methods such as cheques or cash have very little protection sadly.#xDMore OnThomas Cook Group Ltd.Thomas CookThomas Cook collapse

Stephanie Kaye, , described how weeping staff were overwhelmed when Brits presented them with two carrier bags stuffed with cash.Fellow passenger Tommy Laing posted on Facebook: I’ve Just landed in Manchester from Vegas, was flying with Thomas cook, the staff told us mid flight that they’d just been told half way through the flight that we were on the last Thomas cook flight anywhere, they had just lost their jobs and would not be getting paid this month- they were all in tears!Soon as we landed a Scottish girl stands up- right folks I’m having a whip round get your money out £ each! Andthat’s not the most Scottish thing ever I don’t know what is was a joyful moment! Got £ apparently. Stephanie, from Leeds said the  passengers were made aware of the companies fate by the pilot - who told them that staff wouldnapost be getting paid for the journey mid-air.She said: When we got on the plane, the staff were really friendly and professional.    One of the staff members made an announcement at the beginning of the journey to say they knew as much as we did, so please bear that in mindyou hear anything.And she said,youaposre that way inclined, please say a little prayer for us and it got a bit emotional as everyone started clapping.Staff were so professional during the flight, they didnapost mention it, but as soon as we landed, they got the news.At the end, the pilot came over on the tannoy and said aposThataposs the end of our dream.aposAnd he mentioned how staff wouldnapost be getting paid so he asked us to thank the rest of the crew.Then, everyone clapped again and staff were in tears and thanking the passengers for making it a nice flight.But towards the end of the journey, passengers had started a little collection but it ended being quite a big collection.Everyone was putting in their remaining dollars and I think there was two bags going around so it turned out to be a lot of the money.People were very generous, they were throwing in wads of dollars, it was two carriers bags worth of coins and notes.And it got handed over at the end of the flight and staff came over the tannoy, they thanked us again for the support, and said how overwhelmed they were.It was really emotional, passengers were crying. Itaposs crazy that staff didnapost know about it  until landing.The -year-old had driven from San Francisco to Las Vegas over two weeks with her partner Anouj Patel,  and arrived back at Manchester Airport this morningShe said: You could not have faulted the staff, they were great.At the end of the flight, you could tell they were really emotional but they still thanked people for flying with them and wished them a good day.  Passengers on a separate Thomas Cook flight, from Orlando, also donated money after an on-flight whip round.A touching video of the generous passengers shows them praising the now-bust company staff for their honorable behaviour and wishing them good luck. The passengers were lucky to have made theirflight after up to , Thomas Cook holiday makers have been left stranded abroad following the overnight collapse of the -year-old travel giant. A staggering , jobs are now on the line, including , in the UK alone, after the company failed to secure a deal with creditors and shareholders that could plug a £m gap in its finances.Describing the emotional atmosphere on board the flight, one lucky couple ing from Orlando, Grant and Katie Speers, told Sky News: It was emotional, staff didnapost know what was happening until they landed. I take my hat off to them, the way they conducted themselves.  Rebecca Dooley, who was also on the flight, added: I felt for the crew, but they were dignied. Now-redundant Thomas Cook workers have taken to Twitter to share their despair at having lost their jobs. One former Thomas Cook representative who also happened to be among the passengers being repatriated this evening took to the  to say she has been crying for staff and memories of times passed. Meanwhile, an axed Thomas Cook worker pledged to stand outside closed travel agents she used to work at in order to help affected customers.

story: NewsWe bought £, Thomas Cook holiday to New York knowing wed never go on itEXCLUSIVE: Chris and we Steph had been saving Thomas Cook vouchers for a dream Disneyland family holiday but spent them before they became worthless just hours before Thomas Cook went bustShareCommentsByAndy Rudd:,  SEP Updated:,  SEP NewsChris and Steph waiting to fly away on a previous holiday"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShrewd dad-of-five Chris King walked into a Thomas Cook shop just hours before they went bust and spent £, on a holiday to New York using vouchers which could now be worthless. Chris and his we Steph had been saving the vouchers for a dream family holiday to Disneyland for when his three children, two-year-old twins Eloise and Theo and Xanthe, , were old enough. But after hearing that Thomas Cook were on the verge of going bust, he rushed down to his local store in Reading, Berkshire, and splashed out on last minute holiday just two hours before they closed in the hope he would be covered by ATOL protection. Chris, , said: I walked in the shop and the three of them, stopped and looked at me like I was an outsider walking into a western bar. I think they thought I was crazy. I felt bad going into the shop but had I not done it then the vouchers could well have been worthless. It was a bit of an awkward situation because one of the ladies had been working there for  years. I said to them aposI know you might be out of a job but can you help me outapos. She replied aposletaposs book somethingapos.Have you been affected or did you work for Thomas Cook  Email webnews@mirrorChris then went through the whole process of booking a holiday that he knew he wouldnapost be going on.We chose a long weekend in New York for May next year. We hadnapost done any research so we were sitting there looking at hotels and trip advisor reviews. We chose the Millennium Hilton in downtown. Chrisapos we, Steph, , had won the vouchers as an award at work. Project manager Chris added: Because we wanted to spend all the vouchers we even upgraded to premium economy class. When the lady went through to the Thomas Cook booking line and explained she had a customer wanting to book a holiday I think they were a bit surprised.      She printed off the receipt, booking reference. Our flights were through Virgin so when I got home I logged on and chose our seats.It was bittersweet - booking a holiday we knew we wouldnapost be going on.   We woke this morning to hear that Thomas Cook had gone bust. Weaposre lucky because weaposre not stranded anywhere and weaposre, hopefully, not out of pocket. Now I just need to work out how to claim our money back. Thomas Cook collapsed and entered compulsory liquidation in the early hours of this morning. The collapse has put , jobs at risk, including , in the UK, and resulted in all of the companyaposs flights and holidays being cancelled. Last-minute talks to try and save the worldaposs oldest travel firm failed last night as more than , customers were on trips abroad.

title: huge 10 stone great dane
story: NewsHuge  stone Great Dane savages baby in front of mum and granBrittany and Michelle Eling saw Harvey the rescue dog attack young Olivia while she played on the floor of the grandmas Texas homeShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  SEP Updated:,  SEP NewsBrittany watched on in horror as the dog went for her daughter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA terried mum and grandmother looked on in horror as a  stone Great Dane savaged a baby girl. Michelle Eling was watching daughter Brittany, , and one-year-old grandaughter Olivia playing on the kitchen floor of her house in Alvin, Texas. Suddenly the -year-old granaposs rescue dog Harvey approached the baby and attacked her. Before the hound could be stopped it had caused permanent damage to the young girl, nearly ripping off her right ear. The three-foot-tall pooch since been put down after trying to get Oliviaaposs whole head in his mouth. Dog lover Michelle, an accountant, said: “I was standing in the kitchen, Olivia and Brittany were on the floor playing, Brittany was making her giggle.  “I heard Harvey growl. Then I just heard Brittany scream ‘no’, I turned round and saw him lunge at Olivia. “If he hadn’t and he had got hold of her head, I would have had to decide who to save, my pregnant daughter or my granddaughter. All that was going through my mind was, ‘she is not dying in my kitchen’.  There was so much blood, I thought she was going to bleed out. Brittany has three children with chemical plant worker husband, Taylor, , including Mason, three, and Madison, two months. At the time of the attack she was eight months pregnant with her youngest. Regardless, she helped rush Olivia to hospital, where she was kept for two days undergoing one hour of surgery to reattach the tip of her right ear and a two hour skin graft on the top of her head. The attack has left her with permanent scars on her face.  Harvey, who is believed to have been abused by his previous owners, was taken into quarantine for  days by animal control before being put down. Brittany said: “We were supposed to be going home but my Mason wanted to see his grandmother. “It started off normal. I usually tell the dogs to go awaythey approach us but he was been calm. “For some reason I let him come over and out of nowhere he bit her head, he was trying to get her whole head in his mouth.While Brittany remains hopeful that Olivia can’t remember what happened, the youngster is now wary and cautious around other dogs and sometimes wakes up in the night grabbing her ear. “I’ve blocked it out so I only remember bits, the mum continued.I remember my mum and brother trying to pull him away and I put my arm in his mouth. “All I could think was please keep crying because I knewshe was crying then she was alive. “There was blood everywhere. I was pregnant but I wasn’t thinking about me. I just wanted to save my daughter.” Brittany wanted the dog put down, as she realised how close she had come to losing her daughter. But Michelle said she felt sorry for the pooch and blamed his previous owners for the way they had treated him. Michelle added: “It was a complete shock because was a sweet dog, you could just tell he’d been abused. “He didn’t know how to be a dog, he didn’t know how to run and didn’t like going on the grass. “He didn’t have a good le, but he was sweet and he wanted attention. “Shame on the people who owned him before, I just hope in the two months he spent with us it showed him a dferent le. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA remote Greek island is home to crystal-clear blue waters, natural thermal spas - and what is believed to be one of the longest-living populations on earth. The -square mile island of Ikaria claims to have more nonaganerians than any other place on the planet. Research suggests one in three inhabitants of the picturesque island reach the age of .  So itaposs no surprise that researchers have been trying to decode the secret to the elderly islandersapos longevity - finding clues in their Mediterranean diets, midday naps and sex well into their vintage years.    Anthropologists have long pointed to fresh, healthy Mediterranean diets rich in fish and olive oil as an elixir of long-le. The so-called blue zone describes the regions dotted around the world where populations are thought to live the longest. Along with Ikaria, in the Aegean Sea, anthropologists have identied the worldaposs blue zones to include: the Japanese island of Okinawa, claimed to be home to the worldaposs longest-lived women, Costa Ricaaposs Nicoya Pensinsula where there were lower than normal rates of middle-aged mortality, and Italian tourism beautyspot Sardinia. Backed by National Geographic, bestselling author and longevity Dan Buettner and his research team of demographics experts have in recent years explored blue zones including Ikaria in hopes of unlocking their secrets to long le.   He wrote in the New York Times in  of his visit to the island - noting how previous claims of long-living populations were often debunked - but Ikariaaposs reputation held steadfast.Researchers found record-keeping in some villages storied for localaposs longevity meant many people didnapost actually know their own ages. Whataposs more, some beauty-spots discovered that reputations for longevity drew tourism. But researchers in Greece found solid documentation to back Ikariaaposs claims of a long-living population. They discovered locals reached the age of  at two-and-a-half times the rate Americans do.    Successive studies have found the islandaposs villagers were in comparatively better health, and living longer before they were beset with cancer, cardiovascular disease, dementia and depression. A University of Athens School of Medicine study analysed the diet of hundreds of Ikarians, finding they consumed plenty of beans and fish - and ate meat only about five times a month. The Ikaria Study also found the elderly islanders had a diet low in refined sugar but high in olive oil. They noted the islanders consumed two to three cups of coffee and two to four glasses of wine a day. Mr Buettneraposs own research teamaposs interviews found islanders enjoying diets low in heart disease-inducing saturated fats found in meat and dairy, and high in antioxidant-rich and pesticide-free greens grown in their own gardens.

story: NewsWoman stunned to be told she has two vaginas gives birth to miracle twinsLauren Cotter had also been fitted when she fell pregnant with her miracle twins, Maya and EvieShareCommentsByJamie Blue MountainJane LavenderAssistant Editor:,  SEP NewsLauren was born with two vaginas and now has miracle twins, Maya and Evie "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who was stunned when her doctor told her she had two vaginas has given birth to aposmiracleapos twins. Lauren Cotter had suffered from agonising menstrual cramps since she was  and was convinced she had polycystic oy syndrome , a hormonal condition affecting the way the oies work. But an ultrasound scan a year later revealed she actually had uterus didelphys, where a woman is born with two uteruses, two cervixes and, in her case, two vaginas. Now , Lauren insists her condition has never affected her sex le with her police officer husband, Ben, . But she was told she would find it very hard to carry and deliver a child because of the reduced size of her wombs and cervix.    Despite the odds against her, Lauren gave birth to Amelie, five, and Harvey, three. And in an even stranger twist of fate she now has twins Maya and Evie – who were conceived despite her being fitted with a contraceptive implant. In a further quirk of her pregnancies Lauren carried her girls in her right womb while Harvey stayed in her left. She said: From quite early, on Ben and I discussed having children and it was clear that he really wanted to be a dad. “I knew I had to be open and honest and tell him that might not be a possibility for me. Luckily he wasnapost bothered. We talked it through and agreed that there was more than one way to have a babyyou wanted it badly enough. But actually, we have found it easy to fall pregnant – I am not sure why, orit has anything to do with my two vaginas.” After starting her periods aged , Lauren soon began to suffer with painful cramps and heavy bleeding. Consulting her doctor, an ultrasound scan was performed to investigate the symptoms further when she was , revealing she had uterus didelphys.    According to the World Health Organisation, the condition affects around one in , women and occurs when the uterus fails to fuse properly during development in the womb. Lauren said: I can’t remember much about the diagnosis, but I remember hearing PCOS mentioned quite a few times. Up until the ultrasound, there were no signs that I was any dferent to anyone .” A few months after her diagnosis, Lauren had laser surgery to remove the iding wall between her two vaginas, which would enable her to enjoy a normal love le. She said: I didn’t think much about it at the time. All I remember is being told I was going to need surgery to give me a normal le later down the line - but they didnapost go into any specics. A year later, when she was , she met Ben through mutual friends and happily intimacy was no problem for the pair. With their relationship going from strength to strength, Lauren and Ben got married in a mansion house in Melbourne in  and a year into their marriage decided to start trying for a baby.    But, while fertility itself was not an issue, she had been warned that being able to safely carry a baby to full term may not be possible, given that her wombs were half the average size. So, the newlyweds were expecting the road to parenthood to be fraught with dficulties - until Lauren fell pregnant with Amelie in October  after just a month of trying. She said: We decided to give it a go, and just see what happened. We knew it might be a bumpy road and tried not to get our hopes up too much. “Just a month after we started trying, I bought a stack of pregnancy tests and started taking them weekly. Then one morning, I had a test to hand, and there on the stick was a very, very, faint blue line. I couldnapost be sure, so I took a test each morning that week, and each day the line got darker and darker until I was sure - we were pregnant. With doctors carefully monitoring her pregnancy to key an eye on the baby’s development, Lauren initially hoped she would be able to carry the baby to full term. Lauren added: My obstetrician was quite honest with me and explained that, as I have two cervixes, it physically isnapost possible for me to fully dilate enough for the baby to pass through.  “Therefore, I’d have to have an early delivery via C-section. Despite her initial disappointment, Laurenaposs pregnancy went smoothly and baby Amelie was delivered by caesarean section on June , , at Melbourne’s Mercy Hospital for Women, weighing a healthy lb oz. Settling into family le, the couple decided to start trying for baby number two around  months later. Once again, after just two months, Lauren fell pregnant and was surprised to discover at her first scan at five weeks that her baby was growing in her left womb, not her right, as before. She said: I carried Amelie in my right, and just assumed the left one was a dud. Following another problem-free pregnancy, Harvey was delivered, once again by caesarean, at  weeks. Arriving at the Mercy Hospital for Women, he weighed lb oz, and, after initially struggling to swallow on his own, was allowed home after three weeks. Already busy raising two young children, Lauren was unsureshe wanted to try again right away so,  months after having Harvey she was fitted with a contraceptive implant on the advice of her consultant.    Lauren said: The pill was giving me migraines and I couldnapost use the coil, so in the end the implant was the only option left. Itaposs one of the complexities of having my condition - they have to take two swabs every time I go for a smear test too. According to the NHS, the implant is more than  per cent effective – but remarkably, just three weeks after having it fitted, Lauren made a shocking discovery. She said: This feeling came over me, and on some level, I knew I was pregnant. The day my period was due, I dug out a pregnancy test, and within minutes my suspicions were confirmed.” Then, at her nine-week scan, Lauren, who suspects she conceived the day her implant was fitted after a misunderstanding about the window period in which she could fall pregnant afterwards, was left reeling once again when she discovered she was expecting twins. She said: Shocked doesnapost begin to cover it. During  years together, Ben and I had only ever got pregnant when we’d planned it. Now, here we were, having surprise twins. Concerned about how long Lauren would be able to carry twins due to her condition, doctors put her on strict bed rest from  weeks onward.    She said: My doctor was very honest and said he couldnapost know how the pregnancy was going to play out. Slowly ticking off the days, by the  week mark the babies were ready to be delivered and on June , , Maya and Evie were born – by caesarean like their siblings - weighing lb oz and lb oz respectively. While they initially seemed perfectly healthy, drama struck just hours after their arrival when Evie began struggling with her breathing and was sent to intensive care. There, an X-ray of her lungs was ordered, which showed she was suffering with congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which occurs when a baby is born with their intestines in the chest cavity. At just five days old, she had keyhole surgery, which her parents were warned she had just a  per cent chance of surviving and could have meant her staying in hospital for up to eight months before she was ready to be discharged.

title: blether ref and committee man had different tallies for famous 36 0 arbroath win
story: Last week, Rob Boag gave a slightly dferent version of events to the one which sees a famous scoreline as a world record – Arbroath  Bon Accord .In the second part of his tale, he continued: “The Dundee Harp v Aberdeen Rovers KO time was pm at Harp’s ground on East Dock Street and the half-time score was Harp , Aberdeen Rovers .“The second half was even more incredible. The Sunday train to Dundee would be too late for Tom, he walked and jogged all the way from Arbroath to Dundee, and sought out Harp officials to confirm the Arbroath score.“Do we have time to change yesterday’s score to the ref’s tally of Harp  Aberdeen Rovers  “Tom and the committee lads then went off to the referee’s house.”

title: gaffer mcpake feels dundee need to win every game to push for promotion

title: jamie ness touch and go for dee clash in greenock
story: Dundee are sweating over the fitness of Jamie Ness ahead of today’s trip to face Morton.The experienced midfielder is “touch and go” according to Dark Blues boss James McPake for the Championship clash at Cappielow.The -year-old former Rangers and Stoke City man picked up an ankle injury against Cove Rangers in the Betfred Cup before exacerbating that issue against Elgin City in the Challenge Cup a fortnight ago.And gaffer James admits it is still a niggling problem for Ness.“Jamie Ness is still touch and go. Again it’s a niggling thing,” he said.“It goes back to that tackle up at Cove and then the tackle the other week.“It’s a bit of bone bruising and swelling in his ankle that we’re doing our best to get rid of and get him going at it.”Despite that bad news, James was quick to make the point that the rest of his squad are available and is pleased with the options at his disposal. vw, px"  He added: “Everybody  is fine.“There’s strength in depth, that was a big thing we needed to do.“You need that because we’ll get injuries and suspensions, loss of form and times where you might need to change the team for your opponent.“We’ve got players here that give us a good mixture. For example, Kane Hemmings sat there with Andrew Nelson last Saturday and what a luxury that is to have that quality on the bench.“It’s important and throughout the season everyone will be needed.”Gaffer James was particularly happy with namesake Josh McPake’s performance in the - win over Alloa last week and has also put any doubts over his fitness to bed.He said: “Josh McPake has trained and he’s fine.“He was good against Alloa, we knew bringing him to the club what qualities he had.“I’ve seen a lot of him over the years, mainly because he pops into my head quickly because he has the same surname.“You take an interest in him but he was great, very direct and had loads of attempts on goal.“The front three, in particular, were really good in the first half of that game. They created loads of chances and got the ball into the box.“Josh has got that where he can go at people. He sets up the second goal and I was happy with him.”

title: playtime for youngsters as trail opens at dundee primary school
story: Young children’s imaginations have been running wild as they enjoy active play on a new wooden trim trail area at their school.Pupils at Downfield Primary School gave the seal of approval to their new outdoor play area at its official opening.The event brought together many people who helped make the new play area possible, including members of Downfield PS Parent Partnership, who raised £, towards the total cost of the project.The other £, was paid for using a grant from Strathmartine Regeneration Forum’s community fund, at Dundee City Council.The equipment has been a roaring success with the kids since it was installed.Karen Emmett, the school’s head teacher, said: “As soon as the fencing came down and the contractors were out, the children were all over it. It’s been so well used and made such a dference to their playtime.”The area is part of a larger project within the school to promote and encourage outdoor play and education.Karen continued: “The wooden trim trail area allows children to actively play together, socialise and engage in more purposeful play.“They can climb, jump, balance and duck around the horseshoe- shaped structure using lots of dferent active skills.”Pupils helped come up with ideas for the playground and these were made a reality by the school’s parent council.John Anderson-McGuinness, chairman of Downfield PS Parent Partnership, said: “The kids came up with things they wanted to do, rather than asking for traditional equipment.“They said they wanted to climb, use ropes and have a rolling pole that they had seen somewhere , which we managed to incorporate.“The kids think it’s great. They have to be let on in groups because there’s so many of them wanting to go on it at playtime.”John said the partnership has already started gathering ideas from pupils of what they would like to add to the area to extend it in phase two of the project – yet to secure funding.Ideas for this next phase include a seating area and a decked area which could also be used as an outdoor classroom in summer.

title: letters to the editor august 30 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Lochgilphead Medical Centre and Furnace and Inveraray Surgery are delighted to announce a competition for Lochgilphead High School Pupils to design a new name and logo for our services which has been launched in the High School this week.Our name and logo will be changing, but the care we deliver and how we deliver it will not be changing under our current plans.In  the GPs in Lochgilphead took over the surgeries in Inveraray and Furnace. The two practices are run separately but with many shared resources. We don’t think the time is right to merge the practices completely but we do want a new logo and a name that recognises that we work very closely together.The winning entry will receive a cash prize and will then become the public image of our practices for the foreseeable future. In addition, in recognition of their support and contribution to our community, we are also making a donation to the Lochgilphead High School art and design department.We thank all of our patients for working with us over the past few years as changes have been made which require adjustment on all sides. Your understanding and patience is very much appreciated as we seek to find the safest way to deliver the most effective and high quality health care for us all.We look forward to seeing the talent of our local young people when competition entries close on October  and celebrating that talent when we announce our winner on October .Dr Andrew Strain, Lochgilphead Medical Centre and Furnace and Inveraray SurgerySir,My favourite activity at this time of the year is picking brambles. Now I am not saying this is the simplest or even healthiest of activities. All this crouching, hand staining, pricked fingers and even eye strain.Often when you reach for a large black juicy berry it seems to disappear. It’s like the behaviour of politicians. They offer so much but when you reach for it # it disappears. Do you remember the Scottish government passed a law guaranteeing one would be seen by an appropriate health specialist within a stated limited time  The SNP government daily breaks this law – be it on cancer, accident and emergencies, or mental health.Or what about the promises made to the people of Arran and the Outer Hebrides on improved ferry services. The Scottish government is responsible for Caledonian Maritime Assets, CMal, which own and manage ferries. MV Glen Sannox was intended to commence service to Arran in  but lies incomplete for all to see in the Ferguson Marine yard in Port Glasgow. Part of the delay is because of disagreement over the fixed-price design and build contract for the two vessels.The SNP seems obsessed with this type of contract which has adversely affected schools, colleges and community centres. Worse still, while the SNP ridiculed previous government public private partnerships they have introduced a system clearly no better. What about the £. million each month we the taxpayers have to pay for the unopened Edinburgh sick children’s hospital  Jeanne Freeman, the SNP Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care, stepped in so late that she does not know whether this much-needed hospital will ever open.The second part of the bramble experience is the delicious mouthwatering bramble crumble. A crumble which gives joy and stimulation. Not like the crumbling state of the SNP government which has a sour taste and clearly disappoints.Finlay Craig, CoveSir,Your readers may be interested to know that there are currently  people in need of a kidney transplant in Scotland whose diet will be restricted due to kidney disease.It is likely that they will be on fluid restrictions of around just ml of liquid a day # including liquid found in foods like sauces and ice cream. That is roughly the equivalent of only being able to have a small cup of tea and one can of soft drink per day. In addition, they may have to limit the potassium and phosphate in their diet which means missing out on enjoying foods like chocolate, bananas and tomatoes.We want to make the kidney diet about all the things patients can eat and bring enjoyment back into food # which is why we have launched the Kidney Kitchen.We hope that the Kidney Kitchen will mean everyone living with kidney disease in Scotland can enjoy healthy and delicious food with their family and friends.If you are, oryou know a kidney patient, check out www.kidneykitchen.orgEwen Maclean, advocacy officer Scotland, Kidney Care UKSir,The death of a pet cat can come as a shock, and many owners can find it dficult to come to terms with their loss.The death of a pet is not always seen as a signicant loss, leading some people to hide their feelings which can cause them to feel very alone.On Grief Awareness Day, August , Cats Protection is highlighting its free and confidential Paws to Listen support service, so people facing the loss of a cat do not have to feel alone.The service is available on   . Alternatively email pawstolisten@cats.org.uk. For more information, please visit www.cats.org.uk griefCatherine Joyce, Paws to Listen team leader, Cats Protection

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsFestival favourites The Camans, from Inveraray, are all set for this year#s MOJO festival.The popular three-piece band started out in  with its repertoire of lively covers, and has since played around many fantastic venues in the beautul west of Scotland.They have rocked many a festival from Best of the West to Fyne Fest, played at places as erse as Clydebank, Oban and the Isle of Coll and are regulars at Inveraray#s George Hotel.Currently focusing their creative energy on producing their brilliant first EP #The Primrose Path#, The Camans have got MOJO organisers all excited about their debut appearance at October#s event in Ardfern.The Camans trio is comprised of two self-taught music men, Craig McIntyreand Scott Mirrlees# bringing a flowing chord experience like no other # alongside Rhona Robertson, originally from Glasgow, who brings her classically-trained abilities to violin and ukelele. It is all about rich, powerful vocals and plucky guitaring.Craig describes his lyrics as occasionally #cynical# and #rebellious# and the overall sound of the band invites the listener to enter a world of nostalgic delight # making you want to get up and dance.Their style is hard to pigeonhole. You have lovely Scottish-twanged vocals, endearing fiddle playing and the kickdrum beat, and the listener could be forgiven for putting The Camans in a traditional band catergory. But listen closer and you will hear a definite echo of the band#s influences, from Dylan to Guns#n#Roses to the Dixie Chicks. Folk, bluegrass and rock is undoubtedly  there # but look out for a few wee surprises.The Camans have a passion for performing their own, original material and there are even plans for a debut album, so look out for that.MOJO is in for a real treat when The Camans come out swinging on October .PICS:Craig, Rhona and Scott # The Camans. no_aMOJO_Camans

title: letters to the editor september 6 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsDear Mr O#Hara,I write to you regarding your recent undated, round-robin constituency letter and its misleading, generalising and obviously politically biased contents.This is to mention nothing of its scaremongering phraseology and use of expressions such as #crash out# of Europe.Are you seriously suggesting thatwe do not always agree with the Germans that they would stop buying our whisky, fish and tweeds  Or are they not wishing to sell their cars and wine to us  Or visit us as holiday-makers I think not.Your party political bias is only too obvious and you should remember that while you were voted in as MP, it was only by a minority of Argyll and Bute residents, and certainly not by the majority of us.In your snide comments about Boris Johnston # of whom I, too, am not a fan # you give not a single example to back up your contention that he is #causing serious economic and social harm to both Argyll and Bute and Scotland as a whole#.While no-one expects the truth from politicians in general, we do actually expect it at a local level.R Henderson, LochgilpheadSir,The Scottish SPCA is urging the people of Scotland to share their stories, photos and memories of the charity as it prepares to celebrate its th birthday.Set up with the goal of aiding overworked horses and ponies in Leith, Scotland’s animal welfare charity was founded on  December .The Scottish SPCA now has nine animal rescue and rehoming centres and a world-leading wildle hospital in Clackmannanshire. Last year, it rehomed over , domestic pets and successfully released , wild animals back to their natural environment. The society now also delivers industry-leading animal welfare educational programmes to people of all ages.In my short time with the society I know of hundreds of examples of our dedicated people going above and beyond to do all they can for the animals and humans they come across. So, I can only imagine how many fantastic stories must be out there about the people who’ve worn our unorm since we were formed.As well as those who have had a positive experience with us in the recent past, we are hoping to uncover some long lost tales from descendants of those we’ve touched in decades gone by.The society wants anyone with any interesting anecdotes or memorabilia to get in touch via the website or by emailing .years@scottishspca.org.Kirsteen Campbell, chief executive, Scottish SPCASir,The likelihood of the UK exiting the EU has now shted from ‘possible’ to ‘probable’.That gives greater focus to our efforts to prepare and proof our farming industry from the impacts of no deal.Whilst it always has been  the position of NFU Scotland that the UK must secure a favourable deal on the terms of exit with the EU, we must also support our industry through any change in the operating environment.Many NFU Scotland members might think that their businesses won’t be impacted, but the reality is that there will be implications for all of us. Some will be direct and immediate, and others more indirect and emerging through time – but the one certainty is that these will be felt by all of us involved in the agri-food chain.There are a few things that would make a big dferenceapplied right across the board in the UK.First, the UK Government’s proposed import tarf schedule desperately requires revision. It would expose some produce # specically cereals, oilseeds, potatoes, eggs and horticultural produce # to a tarf going into the EU, but would allow that same product to come into the UK with no tarf.This is farcical.To apply asymmetrical tarfs on any products between us and the EU is to completely misunderstand the nature of food security in the UK and fails to recognise that trade is vital to both the UK and the EU.One thing that can be done, regardless of Brexit, is for our own governments to prioritise using our own products when it comes to public procurement.All our politicians like to talk about how good our agricultural industry is in comparison to others across the world in terms of standards and environmental benefits, but we don’t see near enough in the way of Scottish or British products being prioritised for use in schools, hospitals and other public services.Yes, it may add one or two pence to a meal – but I would challenge governments and public procurement buyers what the real cost is of bringing products in from other parts of the world.These products certainly don’t meet our standards – not to mention the impact on climate change with food miles taken into consideration.It’s only a couple of years since the kids in our schools were getting their chicken from Thailand. Things are improving, but it’s still not Scottish chicken.This is within the gt of both Holyrood and Westminster, but it might just be the catalyst for governments to work with local authorities to do the right thing when it comes to feeding those who use our public services.Martin Kennedy, vice president, NFU ScotlandSir,I read with interest the letter from Doctor Strain in the August  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser.Might I suggest that to produce a meaningful logo for the GP practices the following criteria are applied:The logo will need to show:May I suggest there are better ways to provide a service to treat patients, without resorting to gimmicks.Name and address supplied.Sir,I was intrigued to read Finlay Craig’s ramblings in last week#s Argyllshire Advertiser.Would he be willing to share the location of his magical bramble bush for it appears the fruits of this bountul bush, when mixed into a pie, contain mystical properties that can transport the diner to another world May I suggest he tries a cold slice of reality pie now and again which would snap him out of his biased reverie and bring him back to the reality of the UK parliament being suspended and the Scottish representative of the party responsible for that outrageous manoeuvre vacating her post in protest In contrast, the Scottish government is working, along with others, to stop Scotland being dragged out of Europe against its wishes. Or perhaps the suspension of democracy is okay in his dream world If Mr Craig or any of his friends eat too much of his prodigious pie, I am sure they will not hesitate to avail themselves of a free prescription for their malaise and, should they need it, free bus travel to the chemist to pick it up, all supplied by the Scottish Government. If they live on one of our beautul islands, they can soon jump on one of the new ferries being completed as I write, again thanks to the Scottish Government.All this aside, when he rejoins us on planet earth, Mr Craig might think of entering his mysterious pie in the baking section of next year#s Mid Argyll Show, though I think by that time we may all be in need of something a little stronger from Scotland’s political larder to extract us from the bitter reality of Brexit Britain.Charles Ambrose, Lochgilphead.Sir,The National Autistic Society wants to find exceptional people, schools and services making a huge dference to autistic children and adults and their families. If readers know anyone like this, please nominate them for our eighth annual Autism Professionals Awards.It could be an inspirational teacher, a brilliant nurse or doctor, a forward-thinking employer or someone who volunteers their time to support others. We want to celebrate their achievements and share their stories so we can promote innovative autism practice and inspire other people and organisations to help create a society that works for autistic people.Find out more about autism and nominate by visiting autismprofessionalsawards.org.ukCarol Povey, director of the National Autistic Society#s Centre for Autism.Sir,When Ruth Davidson resigned as branch manager of the Tories in Scotland, it was as well she did not upset those who were, and will remain, the real bosses # that is, Boris and co at the London head office.Her claim she #wants to spend more time with her family# is the political equivalent of the schoolchild#s pathetic excuse #Please Sir, the dog ate my homework#.David Hay, Minard.Sir,I am thrilled Macmillan Cancer Support’s World Biggest Coffee Morning is fast approaching.I love a cuppa and it is great you can help people with cancer at the same time so I would love readers to get involved.Macmillan’s World Biggest Coffee Morning raises millions for the ever-growing number of people affected by cancer. Macmillan is not government funded, so without the public’s generous help, the charity cannot provide the services needed in Scotland.Around , coffee mornings are held in workplaces, schools and homes across the country every year. It could not be simpler and more fun to take part # come together as a community in support of people living with cancer and raise money for Macmillan.Macmillan is here to help everyone with cancer live le as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. The charity provides advice and support seven days a week on its free support line as well as through its , healthcare professionals.But demand for Macmillan’s services is constantly growing and it needs your help to support the growing number of people living with cancer.Macmillan’s World Biggest Coffee Morning takes place on Friday September  # but people can host whenever they want. People will be making a dference, however they get involved.Whoever you invite and whatever you serve, you can host your coffee morning your way -i f you can’t bake, that doesn’t have to stop you.Readers can find events nearby using the interactive map on www.macmillan.org.uk coffee.Do something amazing and sign up to host a World’s Biggest Coffee Morning at coffeeregister.macmillan.org.uk. Thank you.Martin Clunes

title: letters to the editor september 13 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirI applaud the letter in last week#s issue from Martin Kennedy of NFU Scotland, calling for our governments and public procurement buyers to ensure that they prioritise Scottish food.I would point to the example of #the Preston model#, where the city council has adopted a #guerrilla localism#. It keeps its money as close to home as possible so that, amid historically drastic cuts, the amount spent locally has gone up as featured inon January ,  which notes #where other authorities privatise, Preston grows its own businesses#.Preston ensures that its resources prioritise local providers and businesses wherever possible. Argyll and Bute Council#s Procurement Strategy   falls some way short of this. Its stated aims commendably include:There is no particular emphasis, however, on using its resources to grow Argyll and Bute businesses, to reduce carbon emissions and food transport miles or to foster healthy eating strategies that would benefit our local farmers through #joining up the dots# of local supply and demand.The climate emergency demands a bolder and more innovative respond, and demands it now.Mary MacCallum Sullivan, ArdrishaigSir,I wish to comment on Mr Henderson#s  open letter to Brendan O#Hara in the September  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser.The expression #crash out# of Europe is used by Conservative members of parliament, the BBC and the press. While emotive, this is what many people directly affected by Brexit feel is happening.For example, on the matter of Germans buying our fish without a trade agreement the tarf will be  per cent on our fish exports to the EU. The Germans will no longer buy our fish.We can all read about other examples of the harm being done in the press every day. The cost of implementing a no deal exit will be borne by all of us, through further austerity , increased taxes , increased national debt or a combination of all three. To my mind, such measures will indeed cause serious economic and social harm.While Brendan O#Hara received a minority of the votes in Argyll, the present government was elected  by less than  per cent of the  electorate.David Inglis, Ardrishaig.Sir,During this, National Air Ambulance Week , may I draw readers# attention to the amazing work of the country#s only charity-funded air ambulance service # Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance .Since  this le-saving service has been flying help and hope to communities all across Scotland in response to serious illness and injury.From our base at Perth Airport, we have responded to more than , time-critical emergencies and impacted on the lives of thousands # and the need goes on.The recently-established Scottish Trauma Network has seen four key major trauma centres created at hospitals in Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen and Dundee. The aim is to transfer all serious patients to one of these centres following pre-hospital emergency care within  minutes.The value of a helicopter air ambulance is therefore obvious.Working alongside the Scottish Ambulance Service#s air fleet, SCAA relies entirely on public donations to keep this vital resource flying.Please consider supporting SCAA in it#s le-saving work during a week when the country focuses on the crucial work of air ambulances everywhere.For further information please visit www.scaa.org.ukDavid Craig, chief executive, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance , Perth AirportSir,I get a magazine called #Clean Slate#.In it this month is an article where a -year-old girl, Greta Thunberg, along with  other youth activists, have issued this invitation to adults around the world: #Starting on Friday September  we are going to kick-start a week of climate action, with a world-wide strike for the climate. We are asking adults to step up alongside us and make this a turning point in our history.#Greta Thunberg was welcomed by the Speaker of the House of Commons, the leader of the Labour Party and the Secretary of State for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. She also spoke at the elite gathering of business leaders in Davos and at the UN.In March , school strikes took place in more than , cities around the world. Again in May, in more than  countries, millions of pupils took to the streets to remind the world that the earth faces a climate emergency.The strike starting on September  coincides with the UN Climate Action Summit in New York. Millions of people in more than  countries will walk out of their work, homes and colleges and spend a day demanding action on the climate emergency.I hear that many in Lochgilphead High School are planning to do the same # well done!Let us join them on Friday September  between am and pm to help build a future fit for all living beings.Mary Stirling, Ardrishaig
